chunks.heading: Up to 40 kVA and 60 kVA energy storage

chunks.content:
The aim of this manual is to provide you with information and basic instructions for the correct installation, transport, maintenance and use of your EHR.

It is essential that you carefully read all these safety rules and warnings before, during and after the start-up of your EHR: only in this way can we guarantee an optimal, regular service in perfect conditions of reliability and safety.

As this document is generic in nature, it is used for a wide range of products with a wide variety of options. Components, instructions or safety standards may appear that do not apply to or are insufficient for the specific equipment you have purchased. In that case you must assess and determine which instructions are valid for your equipment, supplementing them if necessary. Please contact Hi­ moinsa’s Technical Department if you have any doubts.

HIPOWER S.L. considers it honest to point out that the validity of the information described in this manual refers to the date of issuance of the same, since as­ pects such as technological progress and updates of current regulations, may force us to make modifications without prior notice.

This manual and the rest of the reference documentation are part of the EHR you have purchased and must be kept and protected against any agent that may de­ teriorate them. This documentation must accompany the equipment when it is transferred to a new user or owner.

You should always keep this manual close at hand, so you can consult it in case of doubt. Although the information provided in this manual has been verified in detail, HIMOINSA declines any responsibility derived from any calligraphic, typo­ graphical or transcription errors.

In accordance with the European Directives concerning the Defence of Consu­ mers and Users, HIMOINSA is excluded from any liability as a result of incorrect installation, improper use of the machine or breach of the rules indicated in this manual.
chunks.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION

chunks.content:
Before working on the machine, it is important that you read the safety standards indicated in it carefully and that you be aware of any local requirements establi­ shed in terms of safety.

Installation, operation, maintenance and repairs should only be carried out by authorised and competent personnel, and it is the responsibility of the owner of the EHR to carry out these operations in safe conditions. Parts and accessories should be replaced if they are not in safe operating condition.

As a premise to the content of this manual, the following are the basic criteria that, for your own safety and that of third parties, you must follow with special attention.
chunks.heading: 2. SAFETY STANDARDS

chunks.content:
For your own safety and that of third parties, pay special attention to the fo­ llowing basic safety criteria:

• Do not allow any unauthorized persons or anyone using a pacemaker

to access the EHR, due to possible electromagnetic interference in cardiovascular stimulator devices.

• Do not approach the EHR with loose clothing or objects that may be

attracted by airflow or moving parts of the equipment.

• Do not smoke or cause any sparks in the vicinity of the EHR.

• It is forbidden both to cancel and/or disassemble the safety devices

and to modify the configuration of the EHR.

• It is forbidden to lean on the EHR or place objects on it.

In the case of automatically operated equipment, it is also recommended that you:

• Place a red light in a clearly visible position and turn it on when the

equipment is running.

• Place a danger sign warning about the possibility of the machine

starting up unexpectedly.

• Place a mandatory sign stating that “All maintenance operations

must be performed with the equipment turned off and the primary power supply disconnected.”

• To perform an emergency shutdown of the equipment, press the
chunks.heading: 2.1 GENERAL SAFETY PRECAUTIONS

chunks.content: Ask your local authority responsible for waste disposal about the appropriate re­ cycling points. To remove a generator, disassembly without dismantling is recom­ mended.

Distributed around the EHR are safety stickers and information designed to draw the attention of the operator or maintenance technician to potential hazards and explain how to act safely.

A brief explanation of the location is given below, together with information for each one.

• “emergency stop” button, located on the outer panel next to the

protective box.
chunks.heading: 2.3 SAFETY AND INFORMATION STICKERS

chunks.content:
• Respect the rules and regulations relating to acoustic installations.

• Waste maintenance, storage and disposal operations must be carried

out in accordance with the regulations of the country in which the equipment is being used.
chunks.heading: 2.2 ENVIRONMENTAL SAFETY

chunks.content:
Waste disposal work related to the generator should only be carried out by suita­ bly qualified personnel. Suitably qualified personnel are staff who, thanks to their training and experience in EHR maintenance and repair , know about the risks to health and the environment that may derive from the equipment and parts re­ lated to the equipment.

Before starting work, a qualified electrician should check electrical safety. Five safety standards must be respected:
chunks.heading: ACCORDANCE WITH EN 82079-1.

chunks.content:
The safety data sheets of all equipment must be consulted and respected.

Improper disposal may give rise to the following health and environmental risks:

• Burns

• Chemical injuries

• Poisoning

• Bruises

• Soil pollution

• Water pollution

• Air pollution
chunks.heading: 5. Cover or separate live adjacent parts

chunks.content: Loss of Life, Property damage, Installation must always comply with applicable codes, standards, laws and regulations. Faliure to do so will result in death and serious injury.
chunks.heading: 2.5 HAZARDS AND WARNINGS

chunks.content:
•
Automatic starts-up. Disconnect utility power and render unit inoperable before working on unit. Failure to do so will resault in death or serious injury.

•
Risk of injury. Do not operate or service this machine if not fully alert. Fatigue can impair the ability to operate or service this equipment and could result in death or serious injury.

•
Loss of Life. This product is not intended to be used in a critical life supports application. Failure to adhere toto this warning could result in death or serious injury.

•
Equipment damage. Only qualified service personnel may install, operate, and maintain this equipment. Failure to follow proper installation requirments could result in death, serious injury, and equipment or property damage.

•
Personal injury and equipment damage. Do not use equipment as a step.
Doing so could result in a fall, equpipment damage, unsafe equipment operationg, and could result in death or serious injury.

•
Loss of control. Do not park the unit on a steep grade or slope, even if using a parking break. The unit coulf suddenly roll, move, or tip, which could cause death, serious injury, property or equipment damage.

Important Notes:

See individual unit specifications for required maintenance and run times pretaining to use.

1.
Connecting the EHR to the electric utility grid must only be done after recieving prior approval from the utility company.

2.
Protection against lighting surges in accordance with locak electric codes are the responsibility of the installer.

3.
If working on this equipment while standing on metal or concrete, place insulative mats over a dry wooden platform. Work on this equipment only while standing on such insulative mats.

4.
Never work on this equipment while physically or mentally fatigued.

Some of the stickers referred to here may not be needed for your EHR model and may not be included in the equipment.
chunks.heading: GENERAL HAZARDS:

chunks.content:
The EHR supplied by HIMOINSA is intended for the conversion and optimisation of electrical energy according to the environmental and operational conditions and limits indicated or agreed in the contract. Any modification of these condi­ tions and limits must be communicated to the factory directly or through authori­ sed workshops designed to achieve optimal operation and, where appropriate, to provide new modifications and / or calibrations to the equipment.

The EHR is an energy conversion and optimisation system intended for energy distribution facilities that must be operated by specialists in accordance with cu­ rrent standards. Although the recharging powers may be lower than those of a public supply grid, the danger inherent in electric power is the same. The EHR is a production plant that, in addition to the electrical risks inherent in a power su­ pply from a public supply grid or generator set, is also subject to the dangers de­ rived from lithium batteries (explosion, gassing, spillage).

Any use that has not been previously agreed with HIMOINSA should be conside­ red as improper use and, as such, is not acceptable.

•
Equipment or porperty damage. Do not block air intake or restrict proper air flow. Doing so could result in unsafe operation or damage to unit.
chunks.heading: 2.4 WARNINGS IN THE EVENT OF MISUSE

chunks.content:
•
Electrocution. Do not wear jewlery while working on this equipement. Doing so will result in death or serious injury.

•
Explosion. Do not dispose of batteries in a fire. Batteries are explosive.
Electrolyte solution can cause burns and blindness. If electrolyte contacts your skin or eyes, flush with water and seek immediate medical attention.

•
Electrical Shock. Disconnect battery ground terminal before working on battery or battery wires. Failure to do so coul lead to death or serious injury.
chunks.heading: BATTERY HAZARDS:

chunks.content:
•
Fire and explosion. Installation must comply with all local, state, and national electrical building codes. Noncompliance could result in unsafe operation, equpiment damage, death or serious injury.
chunks.heading: FIRE AND EXPLOSION HAZARDS:

chunks.content:
•
Electricution. Veryify electrical system is properly grounded before applying power. Failure to do so will result in death or serious injury.

•
Personal injury and equipment damage. User access prohibited. Do not open the enclosure. No user servicable parts inside. only qualified servicer personnel may install, operate, and maintain this equipment. Noncompliance could result in personal injury or equipment damage.

•
Electrical shock. Only a trained and licensed electrician should perform wiring and connections to unit. Failure to follow proper installation requirements could result in death, serious injury, and equipment or property damage.

chunks.heading: ELECTRICAL HAZARDS:

chunks.content:
The EHR is a device that makes it possible to manage energy in stand-alone sys­ tems of gensets and / or renewable energy sources. In addition, when integrated with diesel generator systems, it optimises efficiency, noise, emissions and fuel consumption. It should be noted that it is a power generation system designed for the rental market.

The HICORE energy control module is the brain of the unit, consisting of a control panel that allows high-level unit supervision, monitoring and control. This control module, together with the C4CLOUD device that incorporates GPS global positio­ ning technology, makes it possible to record and send data to the EHR PORTAL.

The EHR PORTAL is an energy management platform (EMS) that allows the user to control and optimise the energy consumed, in addition to monitoring and re­ porting on each equipment or the entire fleet of equipment owned by the user.
This management can be done by both proprietary users and fleet managers and service engineers.

HICORE provides the best resources to manage your energy storage, allowing you to get the most out of the system and respond to your customers’ needs more effectively.

This manual will guide you in the steps required to operate this equipment co­ rrectly and in a safe and efficient way, allowing you to manage the energy savings that the equipment will provide throughout its operational life.

It is mandatory to create a connection between the EHR and the ground, always in compliance with local rules and regulations. Depending on the grounding sys­ tem to be implemented, a connection must be made to the ground or to the EHR.
A chassis plate and a grounding plate are included and, depending on the groun­ ding system to be wired, these plates must be bridged or not.

For a proper connection, one or more grounding rods must be wired. It should be noted that when a “grounding rod” is mentioned, this refers to a physical groun­ ding connection. It is usually done by placing a copper bar (grounding rod) in the ground. But depending on the location of the system, it can also be a copper plate or strip buried in the ground, the water supply grid, or the water pipes of a house.

EHR equipment allows connection with TNS, TT and the IT grounding system.
Listed below are the steps to follow to connect each of the grounding systems.

UPS function

The EHR can be used as an offline uninterruptible power supply (UPS). In the event of a grid or power supply failure, the EHR will continue to supply power to the output loads.

The change of status is less than 20 ms with zero interruption of the output supply, which means there will be no interruptions in power.

HICORE incorporates an operating mode intended exclusively for this function
(see 5.10 Working modes | UPS mode). It requires no user intervention and will continue to power the output until the EHR power storage runs out. If the primary power supply is detected once again, it will supply power to charge the EHR battery to ensure it is ready for the next power outage.

Power assist

The Battery Assist (Power Assist) function is automatically activated when necessary, without the user having to take any action.

The power assist function is activated when the load demand rises above the input limit of the AC source. When activated, the inverters synchronize with the
AC source and add the power to the incoming power. This feature is useful when a load demand is needed at intervals that the AC source cannot supply.

Each EHR model has a minimum power value that the primary power supply must have for the power assist to work. If it doesn’t, the system will not run properly.
Therefore, when choosing the primary power supply, note that these vary depending on whether it is an electricity distribution grid or a generator set:

chunks.heading: 3.6 STANDARD ENVIRONMENTAL REFERENCE CONDITIONS

chunks.content:
Noise.

Information on the EHR sound protection level and the emission sound pressure level at the operator position is specific to each EHR model. This data can be found at:

• Weighted sound power level: consult this value in the CE declaration

as well as in the marking of the equipment.

• Uncertainty: check with the manufacturer for each model.

• Sound pressure level: Check with the manufacturer for each model.

Sound power level measured in accordance with Directive 2000/14/EC, as amended by Directive 2005/88/EC.

• Once the EHR has been received, check that the material received

corresponds to the delivery note, and that the merchandise is in perfect condition.

• To lift and transport the EHR, be sure to use lifting devices of

sufficient capacity and follow the instructions set out in section
4.Unloading, handling and Transport. Any loose or pivoting parts must be securely fastened before lifting the equipment.

• When moving and especially when lifting the EHR, it is recommended

to use the points specifically designed for these functions, previously verifying the optimal state of the lifting points.

• It is totally forbidden to use other retention points, located above the

EHR.

• Any EHR that is damaged, for any reason, during transport, storage

and / or assembly, must not be started-up before a check has been carried out by our specialised personnel.

• If you want to store the equipment until use, it is advisable to have a

room properly protected from chemical agents that can deteriorate its components.

• Unpacking must be carried out carefully, avoiding causing damage to

the material during such operation, in particular when levers or metal utensils are used.

[ 1]

[ 2]
chunks.heading: 4. UNLOADING, HANDLING AND TRANSPORT

chunks.content:
• Check that the equipment is clean, that the surrounding area and

leakage routes are clean and unobstructed. Check for obstructions in openings or grooves.

• Check if personnel are working on other equipment in the area and if

such work is hazardous and affects the operation of the facility.

• In the case of installations in environmental or operating conditions

other than those designed by the EHR, consider the possible correction factors to be applied. This information can be found in the data sheet or on the identification plate of the equipment, section

• The installation of the EHR and its corresponding accessories must

be carried out by specialised personnel. In case of any difficulty during the installation, please contact HIMOINSA’s Technical
Department.

• You must know the emergency procedures related to the installation

to be performed and it is advisable to have a fire extinguisher in the vicinity of the EHR. You can check with the fire department for more information related to fire prevention.

• Always wear a protective helmet, footwear, safety gloves, goggles, and

dry, close-fitting clothing.

• Do not modify the original protectors, located on all exposed rotating

parts, hot surfaces, air intakes and live parts.

• Do not leave disassembled parts, tools or any accessories on the

equipment, in its vicinity or inside the EHR.

• Never leave flammable liquids or flammable cloths soaked in liquid

near the equipment (including lamps).

• Take all possible precautions to avoid risks of leakage. Ground the

common point of the EHR designed to be grounded. Ensure that this grounding has been carried out in accordance with the relevant regulations. For more information, see Section 6.1.7 General
Guidelines. Grounding.

• Place a "DO NOT MANOEUVRE" sign on all the circuit breakers that

isolate the parts of the installation on which work is to be carried out.

• Install the necessary safety protections on the parts that complete

the installation.

• Isolate all disconnected links and wires. Do not leave the EHR power

terminals exposed.

• Check and ensure that electrical power links and auxiliary services

are performed correctly.

• Make sure that the power cords you install meet the requirements

of the relevant regulations, as the use of inappropriate cables can cause serious damage to both equipment and people (due to dangerous electrical conditions).

• Check that the equipment's shutdown devices are in perfect working

order.

• Check that the ventilation is working properly - hot air from the

inverters must be expelled into the atmosphere.

• Locate the position of all fire extinguishers and other protective and

emergency devices and know how they work.
chunks.heading: 4.1 SAFETY DURING INSTALLATION AND INITIAL START-UP

chunks.content:
• The power lines that power the equipment must be connected to the

equipment before the equipment is put into operation.

• Stop the EHR immediately if you detect any type of abnormal

operation, such as excessive vibrations, leaks, fumes, or loss of output power.

• Keep the body doors closed in case it is exposed to the outside.

Otherwise, if it is located in a dry and clean place, you can leave the doors open.

• Maintain adequate ventilation to ensure that your EHR works properly.

Without this ventilation, accidents or property damage could be caused.

• Safety labels should be kept clean and in places predetermined by

the manufacturer.

• Any checks and / or maintenance on the EHR must always be carried

out by specialised personnel.

• Maintenance interventions should be performed with the EHR shut

down. If the equipment is shut down after a period of operation, wait for it to cool down, be careful not to burn yourself, as some components may be extremely if the equipment has just been shut down.

• Before operating on any component of the electrical installation, turn

off the equipment (See "6.3 Disconnection of storage equipment").

• Before opening the electrical panel, authorized personnel must

disconnect the equipment (See "6.3 Disconnection of storage equipment").

• Periodically check both the tightening and insulation of the

connections.

• Any operation and/or maintenance procedures not expressly

indicated in the user manuals must be notified to the manufacturer for approval.

• Do not make modifications to the product without the knowledge and

express authorisation of our Technical Department.

• Spare parts must correspond to the requirements defined by the

manufacturer. Only use original spare parts. For spare parts, please only contact authorised spare parts distributors or workshops in the
chunks.heading: 4.3 SAFETY DURING MAINTENANCE

chunks.content:
• Do not allow people who do not know the safety conditions, children

or animals to access the operational area of the EHR.

• The person responsible for operating the EHR must remain alert

and in the necessary conditions for an adequate response and interpretation. He or she must never operate it while psychically or mentally fatigued or under the influence of medication, drugs or alcohol.

• It is recommended that there be a minimum of two people during

operations that may pose a health risk, especially electrical risks.

• Do not touch the EHR, especially the cables, copper terminals, and

exposed connections, while the equipment is running, as they are live. In the case of electric shock, the first thing to do is to stop the equipment. If this is not possible, try to free the victim from the electrical power source using a non-conductive element. If the victim is partially or totally unconscious, perform cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and seek medical assistance immediately.

• Do not touch the equipment until the EHR is completely turned off.

• Never connect loads higher than the POWER RANGE of the EHR.

• The lines of the planned loads to which the generated power will be

supplied must always be connected to the equipment before the start-up of the equipment.
chunks.heading: 4.2 SAFETY DURING OPERATION

chunks.content:
• HIMOINSA support grid. For a correct determination of spare parts,

always specify the data indicated on the equipment plate, and the type of EHR.

• Periodically monitor the status of the different components of the

• Periodically watch out for electrolyte leaks in the batteries.

• Do not regulate your equipment for a performance other than those

provided by the manufacturer.

• Do not touch the power supply ducts when the equipment is in

operation.

• When working on parts that may be live, always check that your

hands and feet are dry. We recommend the use of insulating platforms when performing manoeuvres.

• Always keep the EHR clean, removing any stains.

• Do not perform tasks that require the presence of several people

on your own, especially when operations must be performed on manoeuvring parts such as switches, disconnectors, fuses and / or live devices.

• Periodically check the battery terminal connections to make sure they

are clean, airtight, and weatherproof.

• Do not make any changes to the DC bus of the batteries. It is enough

to check the DC bus to make sure the terminals are tight enough.

• Battery maintenance should be performed or supervised by personnel

with knowledge of the batteries and the necessary precautions.

• When replacing batteries, make sure they are of the same type and

number.

• Do not throw the batteries into a fire as they can explode. Do not

open or mutilate the batteries as the electrolyte released is harmful to the skin and eyes.

• Batteries should only be replaced by the manufacturer or authorised

personnel. Handling batteries or control systems can be dangerous and will invalidate the warranty.

• Batteries in some countries are considered hazardous waste. Use

the appropriate containers or contact an institution responsible for the collection of this type of waste.

chunks.content: The installation of the EHR must be carried out by qualified personnel, in accor­ dance with the regulations in force in the country where the installation is to be carried out.
chunks.heading: 5. START-UP AND OPERATION OF THE EHR

chunks.content: To carry out the installation, a series of general considerations must be taken into account, regardless of where the EHR is located. Complemented by the spe­ cific recommendations of each installation, shown in this section..
chunks.heading: 5.1 INSTALLATION: GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS

chunks.content:
It should be verified that the EHR doors can be fully opened, that access for maintenance and overhauls is possible, and that the cooling system is working properly.

The location of the EHR is of utmost importance because the proximity of the power supply and its grounding point must be taken into account, proper ventila­ tion (leaving at least one meter on all sides of the unit and making sure that the hot air flows that may be generated by the internal elements are directed away from the equipment). The unit should be placed upright on a flat, solid surface.
Make sure the unit is not in danger of being submerged in water.

In general, the area where the EHR is installed must be properly fenced off to prevent access by unauthorised persons. Appropriate prohibition and danger sig­ ns should be placed in visible areas.

VENTILATION

The ventilation of the EHR plays a key role in its proper functioning and durability.

Improper ventilation can cause excessive temperatures around the EHR or inside the gensets, causing overheating and loss of operational efficiency.

Adequate ventilation should have the following characteristics:

The following premises must be taken into account:
chunks.heading: LOCATION OF THE EHR.

chunks.content:
people, the electrical installation and the equipment, the customer must ground the EHR.

To carry out grounding, the EHR contains a main grounding terminal. The custo­ mer shall connect his grounding rod to the grounding installation of the equip­ mm2.

The materials, dimensions and depth of the grounding rods must be chosen in such a way that they resist corrosion and present adequate mechanical resistan­ ce. They should be installed vertically in the ground. The resistance of a groun­ ding rod depends on its dimensions, its shape and the resistivity of the soil in which it is embedded. This resistivity is usually variable from place to place and varies with depth.

The choice and sizing of the grounding conductors and rods will be the responsi­ bility of the installer who performs the installation, taking into account the local and national regulations applicable in their jurisdiction.

After consulting the general installation instructions, shown in the previous sec­ tion, and the corresponding regulations, if the EHR is being installed outside, special attention should be paid to the noise generated, the environmental condi­ tions and the influence of seasonal and meteorological changes on the characte­ ristics of the soil and the environment.
chunks.heading: OUTDOOR INSTALLATIONS.

chunks.content:
These operations should be performed in the following situations:

• Before start-up.

• After the installation of the equipment.

• After a general overhaul.

• After performing maintenance operations.

• After a long period of inactivity.

• Heat from other sources should be considered in the design of the

ventilation system.

• The design of the ventilation system of the equipment will be carried

out with all doors closed.

• The EHR will be installed depending on the direction of the prevailing

winds, both indoors and outdoors.

The altitude at which the genset is installed must be taken into account since the greater the altitude the lower the density of the air, requiring a greater flow of air than equipment located at sea level.

The choice and sizing of the cables is the responsibility of the installer who per­ forms the installation, depending on the type of cable and the current regulations that are applicable in the country in which the installation is carried out.

Power cables must be connected to the line terminals located at the bottom of the electrical panel, and must be located in suitable conduits, tunnels or cubicles carrying protective conductors. It is recommended that cables of different volta­ ges be separated by a minimum distance between layers of 25 cm, always pla­ cing those with the highest voltage in the deepest area, thus avoiding possible magnetic interference.

Primary power supply input

Maintenance input

Connecting the automatic start-up of a generator set.

The generator set’s remote start-up terminals are located on the lower door. This is the connection that is used to send a start or stop signal to a generator set using its automatic start-up cable. EHRs include these connectors so that a pro­ per connection is made with whatever genset the user owns.

When setting up a hybrid system, the overall performance of combining an EHR with a generator set can be improved by making some simple adjustments to the type of generator set.

In auto-start mode, some types of generator sets start running as soon as a start signal is received. Others, however, have a number of delays that can pre­ vent a diesel generator set from starting up and generating power as quickly as possible. These delays should be minimised whenever possible. Otherwise, the operation of the operating modes will not be 100% effective.

If you want to “ CHARGE THE BATTERIES ” you must indicate the type of charge to be used, whether a fast charge or a maintenance charge.

Once you have indicated the primary power source, the maximum power of that source will be configured. This data will allow the EHR to control the system to improve the efficiency of the primary energy source and increase its useful life as in the case of generator sets. “ START ”. If we want to finish this operation we must click on the “ASSISTANT “ button that will take us to the tab of the operating mode that is currently running and all we will have to do is press “ STOP ”.

All operating modes include a help function to advise the user at all times. To access this content, you just have to click on the “HELP” button, whose status
LED will have started flashing beforehand to indicate that help is available.

If you are charging a battery, it will not be possible to activate the operating modes, the charging must be disabled and then you can activate the desired operating mode.

Remember that to change the operating mode it will be necessary to press
“STOP ” to halt the operating mode that is currently being used.

In all hybrid working modes that combine the grid / generator set with the batteries, the minimum power delivered by the batteries in any case will be 5Kw.

During the charging process in each working mode, the charge will be limited to the absorption phase of the battery; this means that the battery will be conside­ red fully charged around 97%. To make a 100% charge you must access the battery charging menu.

If no primary power supply (ISLA ) has been chosen beforehand , the only avail­ able operating mode will be “ PLUG & PLAY” because it is not possible to intelligently combine battery charging and charging power using a primary power supply.

The EHR integrates several operating modes aimed at adapting to all the work scenarios that may occur in the electrical system, allowing greater performance and greater adaptability of the equipment currently available in the installations.

PLUG & PLAY mode. The use of the battery and the generator set or grid is enabled dynamically.

UPLOAD SHARE mode. Grid usage is enabled at the same time as battery usage.

Power Booster mode. Only available for genset connection. Working mode designed for starting electric engines.

UPS mode. Only available for grid connection. When the primary power supply is disconnected, the battery will be connected.

PEAK SAVING mode. The generator set or the grid is enabled up to a single power. Beyond this power, any additional energy needed will be delivered by the battery.

chunks.heading: 5.10 WORKING MODES

chunks.content:
“ PLUG & PLAY ” is the default mode for the EHR equipment. The intention is to offer the user a way that avoids having to insert configuration parameters and it incorporates a wide functionality to adapt to most applications. This mode de­ pends on the previous configuration that has been made on the equipment, distinguishing between two functionalities:

When the electricity distribution grid or a generator set has been selected as the primary energy source.

In this case the “PLUG & PLAY” mode will act intelligently by combining three ope­ rating modes:

Thus, for an initial moment in which the loads present at the output are low, the equipment will operate in “ LOW LOADS ” mode, until the threshold defined by de­ fault is exceeded. This threshold is defined as 30% of the maximum power that the generator set or the electricity supply grid can supply. If it is working without any load at all, the EHR will take advantage of this moment to charge the batte­ ries. Once this threshold has been crossed, the generator set will start up or the grid input will be enabled to power the output and charge the batteries if neces­ sary. It should be noted that the genset will continue to work only with the grid or generator set until the maximum performance power of the generator set is rea­ ched, which will be given as 90% of the maximum power that the generator set can supply. If the grid is chosen, this threshold will be given by the maximum power selected by the user. Once this power is reached, the “ PEAK SAVING ” function will be performed, which means that the power of the generator set or grid will be limited to that value while the peaks present at the output will be powered by batteries or by work batteries and the generator set or the grid toge­ ther.

When no primary power supply has been selected, the system will operate in island mode

In this case, the “PLUG & PLAY” mode will only work with batteries, supplying the load by batteries and if using renewable energies, it will charge the batteries and at the same time discharge them to power the load. This mode is recommended for specific uses with very low consumption as this will be when the system

chunks.content:
stops due to a low state of charge.

In any case, to run this mode of operation you just have to select it and then press “ START ”.

When the battery SoC falls below 20%, the EHR will operate at 100% with the generator set or grid until the charging stage is completed. Once the batteries are fully charged, the equipment returns to normal operation. This is the case if we are working in “ LOW LOADS” mode . When this condition occurs during
“ PEAK SAVING ” or “ UPS ” mode, the equipment will shut down in the “PLUG &
PLAY” mode.

Whenever the generator set is turned on or the power grid is enabled, there will be a minimum battery-only operating time until the inverters synchronise with the wave from the connected source.

When starting this operating mode, there will be a delay of [5 – 30] s until the
EHR output is enabled.

RECOMMENDATION:

When a mode shutdown occurs due to an unwanted SoC (<20%), it is necessary to fully charge the batteries externally using maintenance or fast charging. This value may vary slightly by up to 17% by the hysteresis programmed into the system.

This mode is intended to allow energy sources to work in parallel exclusively with the power grid, as well as the battery. To achieve this function, the user must in­ dicate the percentage (%) of energy that he or she wants to feed through the grid, since the rest of the energy will be provided by the battery.

Once this configuration is made, the system will adapt by feeding the load pre­ sent at the output, with the proportion chosen by the user. This mode of opera­ tion is useful to take advantage of solar energy, since on sunny days with the usual demand for energy, the load present at the output can be fed with a propor­ tion of generator set or grid and the rest will be provided by solar energy (if it is greater than the demand, it will charge the batteries and if it is lower, the battery will provide the missing power). When the maximum threshold of supply power, configured by the user, is exceeded, the input will be limited to that value and the rest of the energy will be provided by the battery.

To execute this mode of operation it is necessary to insert the percentage (%) of energy contributed by the grid and then press “ START ”. Below we can see some images that show us what this screen looks like.

[ 3]

[ 4]

[ 5]
chunks.heading: 5.10.4. LOAD SHARING.

chunks.content:
In all EHR models, this is a minimum grid supply value. This minimum value depends on the chosen EHR model, see 4.6. Electrical assistance. The EHR will ignore the percentage selected by the user until that threshold is exceeded.

When the battery SoC drops below 20%, the equipment operates with a 100% percentage of the grid until the charging stage is complete. Once the charging is complete, the equipment returns to normal operation.

This mode is intended to achieve uninterrupted power at the output. To do this, the EHR equipment supplies the loads through a generator set or grid and if the primary power supply disappears, the charge is instantly supplied by the batteries. When the maximum supply power threshold set by the user is exceed­ ed, the input will be limited to that power value and the batteries will provide the missing power.

To run this mode of operation you just have to select it and then press “ START ”.

When the battery SoC decreases by 20%, the equipment will perform a “UPS” mode shutdown.

When a mode shutdown occurs due to an unwanted SoC (<20%), it is necessary to fully charge the batteries externally using maintenance or power input.

[ 6]

[ 7]
chunks.heading: 5.10.5. UPS

chunks.content:
This mode is intended to feed the loads present at the output only by a generator set or grid, except when there are large energy demands, higher than those that can be provided by the generator set or grid. In this case, a limitation on the input is established and the demand for extra energy is delivered by the batteries. You can set the maximum desired power to be provided by the generator set or the grid (this value will be limited to that indicated as the maximum power of the generator set or electrical grid , since this power must never be exceeded). It is important to size the generator set to avoid oscillations, being the minimum group power of the same capacity of the EHR to be used (recommended 30% higher) and perform the PEAK SAVING from 90% of its nominal power. If the value is lower, the system will indicate that the connected group is not powerful enough for this application.

To run this mode of operation it is necessary to insert the maximum power that will be provided by the generator set or the grid and then press “ START ”. Below we can see some images that show us what this screen looks like.

When the battery SoC decreases by 20%, the equipment exits “PEAK SAVING” mode.

When starting this operating mode there will be a delay of [5 – 30]s until the
EHR output is enabled.

When performing a mode shutdown due to an unwanted SoC (<20%), it is necessary to fully charge the batteries externally using maintenance or power

input.

This mode is intended to power low loads only by battery, except when the energy demand exceeds a power threshold determined by the user, in which case the generator set is started up or the grid is enabled to work fully with this power source. When the maximum power threshold, set by the user, is exceeded, the input will be limited to this value and additional power will be provided by the batteries.

To run this mode of operation it is necessary to insert the maximum power at which it is powered by batteries and then press “ START ”. Below we can see some images that show us what this screen looks like.

[ 4]

When the battery SoC is 20%, the equipment will operate at 100% with the generator set or grid until the charging stage is completed. Once the charging is complete, the equipment returns to normal operation.

Whenever the generator set is turned on or the power grid is enabled, there will be a minimum operating time.
chunks.heading: 5.10.7. LOW LOADS

chunks.content:
In this working mode, we take advantage of the overload capacity of the batteries to absorb the power peaks in the load. We configure the minimum state of char­ ge level so that, beyond this level, the generator set starts up.

Once you have selected the level of charge status of the SoC batteries with the help of the cursors ( ) and once you have made the connections, don’t forget to press “START”.

The EHR incorporates the possibility of configuring an operational calendar. This functionality is very useful if you want to restrict the operation of the machine when it is being used by third-party users. To configure the calendar, the user must indicate the days of the week, the time slot and the maximum power at which he or she wants to allow the use of the EHR

Once the calendar has been configured, the user can only use the machine in the configured time slot and when this slot is exceeded, a system shutdown will oc­ cur to indicate to the user that they have exceeded the enabled operating time.
This will take place in the same way for the output power, since if the user ex­ ceeds the configured power, the system will shut down immediately, indicating to the user that they have exceeded the configured power.

If the calendar is active in the main menu, an image of a calendar will appear, thus indicating to the user that the use of the EHR is limited, and it may be the case that the machine cannot work because it is outside the configured time slot.

The “CALENDAR” icon will appear in light grey when the option is enabled and in

dark grey when we are within the time slot in which the EHR has been configured.

Remember to disable calendar ticks when you do not want to restrict the operation. Whenever one of these “ticks” is enabled , the calendar will be enabled, which will make it impossible for the equipment to operate outside the configured time slot.

Remember to set a high enough power to supply the desired installation as insufficient power would cause the system to shut down immediately.

A proper maintenance and overhaul programme, performed only by qualified technicians, is essential if you wish to maximise inverter/battery reliability, minimise repairs and reduce long-term costs.

To carry out an effective maintenance programme, we recommend that you collect the data that are obtained during the work performed, using the EHR uptime meter to keep an accurate record of all the services performed. This record will also be important for security purposes.

To see the specific maintenance plans for the EHR you have purchased, please refer to the corresponding documentation. These plans vary depending on:

• Hours of operation

• Machine location

• Type of load it supplies

• Environmental conditions

In this way, once the equipment has been received and taking into account the aforementioned elements, these maintenance plans must be studied to determine how often maintenance needs to be carried out.

It is important to clean the EHR continuously and to also avoid the accumulation of liquids on both internal and external surfaces. Do not use flammable solvents when carrying out cleaning tasks; it is recommended that you use aqueous liquids for industrial cleaning.

IMPORTANT:

Before performing any operation, shut down the EHR and wait until it cools down.

The EHR requires a regular storage maintenance load when not in use. Connect it to an AC source all the time or at least every 4 weeks, ensuring that a full charge is maintained.

Battery maintenance charging must be done from a single-phase charging source, an electrical grid or a diesel generator set.
chunks.heading: 6. MAINTENANCE

chunks.content:
It is recommended that you leave the AC power supply constantly plugged in. If this is not possible, to maintain the product warranty it is necessary to charge the EHR unit at least every 4 weeks.

When the battery is discharged to 100% (0% SoC) follow these steps:

This procedure should only be performed by qualified personnel.

b.	 Disconnect the power cords from the alarmed module. Isolate the

terminals from the wires to avoid short circuits.

c.	 Disconnect the communication cables.

d.	 Connect the DC power supply to the DC+ and DC- terminals

e.	 Set the power supply to 55 V and charge the modules until the

voltage reaches 51 V.

EHR equipment requires a regular maintenance load when not in use, to preserve its storage capacity. To do this, you should connect an AC source to the maintenance "SOCKET" all the time or at least once a week. In this way it is necessary to maintain a full load and to ensure that the equipment retains all its accumulation capacity.

The maintenance load must be carried out from a single-phase source, either a grid or a single-phase generator set. Remember that we can only supply batteries up to 16A AC through this input.

This section describes the alarms and warnings that may occur during the opera­ tion of the EHR equipment. These alarms must be heeded and as far as possible resolved, which is why a comment is attached next to each alarm and warning to guide the user when he or she has to resolve said alarm or warning. Whenever an alarm occurs, the system will shut down the operating mode and until this alarm is dealt with and resolved it will not be able to use the EHR equipment again. To differentiate between an alarm and a warning, an on-screen abbrevia­ tion is used, thus:

chunks.heading: Differential switch jump, Central, Alarm

chunks.content:
This alarm occurs for several reasons, as it indicates that the master phase has either been deactivated for system security reasons or due to repeated shut­ down of the equipment. When the emergency mushroom is pressed, this alarm appears with the "Emergency Mushroom" alarm, since the emergency mushroom causes a shutdown of the master phase of the equipment and performs an im­ mediate system shutdown. Another cause can be when there is an unsafe condi­ tion for the equipment, for example when there is a very high overload, and the machine shuts down suddenly; in most cases the alarm will appear due to the shutdown and this alarm.

If this alarm is caused by pressing on the mushroom, disengaging it will suffice, but if this alarm occurs because of any other reason and continues to run conti­ nuously, the system should be reset. For more information, see 5.10 Working modes.
chunks.heading: BEEN TURNED OFF (ALARM #1)

chunks.content:
This alarm occurs when the system loses communication with one of the inver­ ters, either L1, L2 or L3. Communication with the inverter can fail for several rea­ sons, including:

- False contacts in the DC distribution of the inverter in question,

either due to the "battery switch" or incorrect tightening torques on the terminals.

- Poor connection of the communication cables between the

inverters and the L1 inverter to the Cerbo GX, due to a worn RJ45 connector or a broken.

- One of the inverters is defective and has stopped working due to

internal causes.

This warning occurs when the battery voltage begins to decrease below a given threshold; this warning does not give rise to any problems as when the SoC is less than 20% a shutdown occurs, and the safety margins are therefore adequa­ te.

If this warning does appear, it is telling the user that the battery is running low.
For more information, see 7. Warning and alarms.
chunks.heading: LOW BATTERY (WARNING #2)

chunks.content:
This warning occurs when a high inversion is being made, close to the limits pre­ sented by the EHR. It is directly related to the temperature warning, since when an overload warning occurs and the ambient temperature is high, the system tends to increase its internal temperature and produces a temperature warning.
If it occurs the other way round, the behaviour is similar: when a temperature warning occurs the system tends to worsen the performance and the EHR increa­ ses the inversion power causing an overload warning. For more information on nominal inversion power values as a function of ambient temperature, see 3.3.
Technical characteristics.

The activation of this warning stems from the overload alarm. With more or less time depending on the power that is being inverted and the ambient temperature at that moment.
chunks.heading: OUTPUT OVERLOAD (WARNING #3)

chunks.content:
This warning appears when the EHR equipment tries to synchronise with the grid and cannot do so because the phase sequence is invalid, that is, it informs the user that the connected phase sequence (either busbar or "SOCKET") is not sui­ table (it performs the function of a phasemeter). When this warning appears, the user must shut the EHR equipment down, reverse the sequence of a couple of phases and then reassemble the system and the EHR should be ready to syn­ chronise with the grid.

For more information, please refer to the on-screen help or see 7. Warning and almars.
chunks.heading: INCORRECT PHASE ROTATION (WARNING #7)

chunks.content:
This warning appears when the charge is only powered by batteries and the state

this problem is to discharge the batteries a little until the alarm is resolved (Low charges, for example) and then perform a maintenance charge so that the inter­ nal cells of the batteries are balanced. For more information, refer to the on- screen help or to 7.Warning and Alarms.
chunks.heading: LOW SOC STATUS (WARNING #10, WARNING #11 AND WARNING #12)

chunks.content: This alarm occurs due to the pressing of the emergency mushroom. To eliminate this alarm the mushroom must be rearmed. Please note that if the emergency mushroom has been pressed, it may be due to a safety condition. Check the con­ dition of the machine and check with the operator who has pressed the emergen­ cy mushroom before rearming it. For more information, refer to the on-screen help or to 7.Warning and Alarms.
chunks.heading: EMERGENCY MUSHROOM (ALARM #51)

chunks.content:
This alarm is due to the differential switch of the EHR equipment that is running.
This is due to a current drift at the output. Before reassembling the magnetother­ mal output check all the wiring and the tightening torque of the terminals. If all is correct, it is possible that this drift is occurring in the installation that is feeding the EHR, so you should check that installation. For more information, refer to the on-screen help or to 7.Warning and Alarms.

Once the problem is solved, reset the magnetothermal output and then rearm the differential switch.
chunks.heading: DIFFERENTIAL JUMP (ALARM #52)

chunks.content:
This alarm occurs when any operating mode is working and the state of charge of the batteries or SoC has decreased by 20%: for safety reasons, the operating mode is shut down. This alarm occurs when the primary power supply cannot be activated remotely or it is supplying the installation at its maximum power, ma­ king it impossible to charge the batteries. It is advisable to charge the battery when this alarm occurs. For more information, refer to the on-screen help or to
7.Warning and Alarms.

This alarm can be related to the previous alarm, "The equipment has been tur­ ned off because one of the phases has been turned off" (Alarm #1), since, if an immediate shutdown occurs due to one of the inverters being turned off during its operation, both alarms can occur instantly. To solve the execution of this alarm, you should refer to the on-screen help or see 7.Warning and Alarms.
chunks.heading: LOW BATTERY OPERATING MODE STOP (ALARM #53)

chunks.content: This alarm appears when the synchronisation between the inverters is erro­ neous, due to a failure of real-time communications. As a result, the system is­ sues an alarm and shuts the operating mode down. In the vast majority of cases this alarm runs continuously and it is necessary to perform a complete restart of the EHR equipment to resolve it, see 5. Starting up the EHR plant. Although it is advisable to perform the steps indicated in the on-screen help, see 7.Warning and Alarms.
chunks.heading: A TIME SYNCHRONISATION ERROR HAS OCCURRED (ALARM #4)

chunks.content: This alarm occurs after the "High inverter temperature" warning. For this reason, you have to previously deal with the warning by referring to the on-screen help, please also refer to 7.Warning and Alarms.
chunks.heading: HIGH INVERTER TEMPERATURE (ALARM #11)

chunks.content: This alarm occurs after the "Output overload" warning. For this reason, you have to previously deal with the warning by referring to the on-screen help, please also refer to 7.Warning and Alarms.
chunks.heading: OUTPUT OVERLOAD (ALARM #13)

chunks.content: This alarm occurs because the BMS of the batteries detects that a cell of the batteries has a voltage that is lower than acceptable, for this reason the system shuts the operating mode down. It is worth mentioning that the best way to solve this problem is to charge the battery, either a fast or a maintenance charge (if a maintenance charge is performed, the internal cells of the batteries should be balanced to achieve a better result). For more information, refer to the on-screen help or to 7.Warning and Alarms.
chunks.heading: LOW VOLTAGE BATTERY (ALARM #38)

chunks.content: This alarm occurs because the BMS of the batteries detects that a cell of the batteries has a voltage that is higher than acceptable, for this reason the system shuts the operating mode down. It is worth mentioning that the best way to solve
chunks.heading: HIGH VOLTAGE BATTERY (ALARM #39)

chunks.content:
This alarm occurs when the calendar is enabled. When the calendar is configu­ red, a period of time and a maximum power will be established. When the insta­ llation is supplied with a power higher than that which has been configured, the mode of operation at that moment will be shut down immediately. For more infor­ mation about configuring the calendar, see Calendar section.

You may wish to refer to the on-screen help for more information, or to 7.Warning and Alarms.

The following is a list of all warnings and alarms that may occur in the system along with their respective help functions to solve each of them.
chunks.heading: THE MAXIMUM CONTRACTED POWER HAS BEEN EXCEEDED (ALARM #55)

chunks.content:
Question
Cause
Suggestion

The unit is turned on, but there is no output power.

The output contactor may not be turned on.

Check in the parameters tab that relay 2 is set to “CLOSE”
The emergency stop may be activated.
Disable the emergency stop.

The magnetothermal output may have tripped

Look at the current record and verify that it has tripped due to excess current

Differential switch may have tripped

Check for any grounding and any current drifts that may have occurred and reset the differential switch

The battery SoC is below 20% and no power source is connected to the EHR.

Connect the primary power supply and charge the battery; it is recommended that a maintenance charge be performed.
The disconnectors between the inverter and the battery are turned off.

Set the disconnectors to “ON”

The external power supply is active (for example, the diesel generator is running) but the EHR is not synchronised.

The phase rotation of the diesel generator or the electrical distribu­ tion grid is not correct

Check the phase rotation of the generator or supply grid.

Damaged cable between the diesel generator or the electrical distribu­ tion grid and EHR.

Check or replace cables and connectors.

The magnetothermal output switch of the generator or the electrical distribution grid has tripped.

Verify that the magnetothermal output switch of the generator or electrical distribution grid is turned on.

The input selector switch may be in the wrong position.

Check the position of the input selector switch behind the distribution door. Note that it has 3 positions: Off/Busbar and
“Socket”. Also make sure that the switch has been fully rotated to the right position.

The system power has been turned on, but it is not displayed on the
HICORE

The HICORE fuse may have been damaged.
Replace the HICORE fuse.

The 24 V DC regulator fuse may have been damaged.

Replace the 24 V DC regulator fuse.
Energy is being sent to the
EHR, but no power is being charged or passed.

The AC magnetothermal input switch may have tripped

Check the position of the AC mag­ netothermal input switch and reset it if necessary.
The external power supply is active (for example, the diesel generator is running) but power only reaches the first phase (L1).

The maintenance load pin may be connected to the grid.

Verify that the maintenance plug is not connected

Damaged cable between the diesel generator or the grid and EHR.

Test or replace cables and con­ nectors.
chunks.heading: 7.4 TROUBLESHOOTING

chunks.content:
columns: Question, Cause, Suggestion rows:
The output voltage is less than 400 V AC at a distance., If the distance between the unit meters, the voltage may decrease., Contact EHR Technical Services to arrange the adjustment of the system configuration.
0% SoC read and AC output
DISCONNECTED., This indicates that the storage voltage has reached its lower limit and has shut down its output to protect the batteries., Charge the EHR from your chosen renewable energy source, from an AC grid connection, or from a secondary power system.
The output switch is activa- ted continuously., Connected consumers are consu- ming too much power for the unit’s rated output., Refer to the maximum output rating on the unit’s nameplate and reduce the total power consump- tion accordingly.
The remote generator set start-up does not work., The generator’s remote start signal cable is loose or damaged., Reconnect or replace the cable.
None, Incorrect remote start-up switching mode (normally open/normally closed)., For more information about changing the switching mode, contact EHR Technical Services for assistance.
None, The diesel generator set is in manual mode., Switch the diesel generator set to automatic mode.
None, Remote start-up of the generator set is not configured correctly., Contact the technical services of the generator set manager.
None, The remote control of the genera- tor set may be set to manual., Set the generator set remote control to automatic.
Diesel generator set run- ning constantly., The EHR may be in manual genera- tor set mode., Check the AC input fuses, connect them, or replace them if neces- sary.
None, There can be a phase imbalance:
too much energy is being consu- med in one phase., Consumers should be evenly distributed across the three stages as much as possible.
None, The load is too high., Reduce the load.
The RCD trips continuously., There is an electrical failure with consumers connected to the AC output., Check the electrical integrity of the consumers connected to the unit.
Output switch on the diesel assembly that is activated at start-up/shutdown., There may be an RCD conflict., Increase the activation current limit on the RCD of the diesel generator set and set the RCD variable to EHR. The adjustment of any RCD must be performed by a qualified electrician in accordance with applicable local rules and regulations.
The output voltage drops when the generator set shuts down.
In charging mode, the unit demands more power than is available in the generator set or power grid., The generator set output voltage is outside the acceptable voltage range for a smooth transition to inverter mode.
HICORE has the maximum power configured for the grid or generator set in the last working mode., Check the phase voltage on the generator set to make sure it is in accordance with the unit’s electrical standards (230 VAC or 120 VAC depending on the configuration).
Please use the wizard to configure any working mode, and to set the maximum power of the generator set or the electrical grid to the current available power.
chunks.heading: 7.4 TROUBLESHOOTING

chunks.content:
If the distance between the unit meters, the voltage may decrease.

Contact EHR Technical Services to arrange the adjustment of the system configuration.

0% SoC read and AC output
DISCONNECTED.

This indicates that the storage voltage has reached its lower limit and has shut down its output to protect the batteries.

Charge the EHR from your chosen renewable energy source, from an AC grid connection, or from a secondary power system.

The output switch is activa­ ted continuously.

Connected consumers are consu­ ming too much power for the unit’s rated output.

Refer to the maximum output rating on the unit’s nameplate and reduce the total power consump­ tion accordingly.

The remote generator set start-up does not work.

The generator’s remote start signal cable is loose or damaged.
Reconnect or replace the cable.

Incorrect remote start-up switching mode (normally open/normally closed).

For more information about changing the switching mode, contact EHR Technical Services for assistance.
The diesel generator set is in manual mode.

Switch the diesel generator set to automatic mode.
Remote start-up of the generator set is not configured correctly.

Contact the technical services of the generator set manager.
The remote control of the genera­ tor set may be set to manual.

Set the generator set remote control to automatic.

Diesel generator set run­ ning constantly.

The EHR may be in manual genera­ tor set mode.

Check the AC input fuses, connect them, or replace them if neces­ sary.
There can be a phase imbalance:
too much energy is being consu­ med in one phase.

Consumers should be evenly distributed across the three stages as much as possible.
The load is too high.
Reduce the load.

The RCD trips continuously.

There is an electrical failure with consumers connected to the AC output.

Check the electrical integrity of the consumers connected to the unit.

Output switch on the diesel assembly that is activated at start-up/shutdown.

There may be an RCD conflict.

Increase the activation current limit on the RCD of the diesel generator set and set the RCD variable to EHR. The adjustment of any RCD must be performed by a qualified electrician in accordance with applicable local rules and regulations.

The output voltage drops when the generator set shuts down.

The generator set output voltage is outside the acceptable voltage range for a smooth transition to inverter mode.

Check the phase voltage on the generator set to make sure it is in accordance with the unit’s electrical standards (230 VAC or 120 VAC depending on the configuration).

In charging mode, the unit demands more power than is available in the generator set or power grid.

HICORE has the maximum power configured for the grid or generator set in the last working mode.
chunks.heading: 7.4 TROUBLESHOOTING

chunks.content:
Please use the wizard to configure any working mode, and to set the maximum power of the generator set or the electrical grid to the current available power.
